title: Christian hardcore

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
> Christian hardcore

I've come to think of this as an oxymoron, like "peaceful war"

although I will say I always thought a lot of rock music had (perhaps I might even say powerful) Christian themes in them

post.title: Christian hardcore

body:
it's a reasonable question, I did a post on rock music being potentially of "the Devil"

the origins of rock and jazz themselves were often associated with rebellion and cultures of sin (drugs, fornication, etc.)

so then people want to "baptize" or "Christianize" the movement, I could see that

But I think it would be like a Christian bikini - bikinis in themselves are immodest, it would be a contradiction to try to make them "Christian"

I guess I think if a Christian has "hardcore" passions of anger, maybe they could try to pour those in to prayer, work, or some other kind of music like religious or dramatic classical
body_html:
it's a reasonable question, I did a post on rock music being potentially of "the Devil"

the origins of rock and jazz themselves were often associated with rebellion and cultures of sin (drugs, fornication, etc.)

so then people want to "baptize" or "Christianize" the movement, I could see that

But I think it would be like a Christian bikini - bikinis in themselves are immodest, it would be a contradiction to try to make them "Christian"

I guess I think if a Christian has "hardcore" passions of anger, maybe they could try to pour those in to prayer, work, or some other kind of music like religious or dramatic classical

body: Seems like your issue though.  I don't think Jesus said spread my gospel but don't get too carried away when you do, keep it off beat and calm now.  He used incendiary language to slander and whip hypocrites, how is hardcore not aligned w that?

body:
I find this convo to be interesting and maybe we could continue it and come to agreement (since I grew up hearing some "hardcore" rock)

the +boomers have in my view done little to address the issue so it's just being dumped on the future generations, which is frustrating

Ok, anyway, so the pope in the early 20th century banned Catholics from dancing and listening to the tango:

https://www.tangoexchange.com/pope-declares-tango-one-of-the-dullest-things-imaginable/

> In November 1913, Pope Pius X declared tango as immoral and off-limits to Catholics.

> According to this article in the Milwaukee Journal in 1914, when tango proved to be too popular for his ban to have any effect, Pope Pius allegedly took a different tact; mocking the tango and trying to renew people’s interest in the “Furiana” (sic: correctly spelled Furlana), a 16th century dance that had gone out of fashion by 1750.  The article claims that after witnessing a demonstration of the dance the Pope annulled the ban on tango, commenting, “It’s one of the dullest things imaginable.”  This story was repeated in newspapers around the world.  However, the Vatican denied that the ban was annulled, or that the Pope had witnessed any such demonstration.

> Dancing Tango was still a sin in the 20th century.

So "moshing" is probably out by the same kind of logic for Catholics, it's an indiscriminately violent dance.

And then the argument would go, if the tango is banned and this is "tamer" than "Christian hardcore music", then such music would also be banned.

I imagine the orthodox would feel similarly, but I don't know

Even among protestants, some of the fundamentalists opposed the tango

So, you'd now be arguing probably on the basis of some kind of "liberal Christian authority", or who are the Christian authorities that have approved of "Christian hardcore"? So the authorities of Catholicism are presumably against it and that would be enough for me, but even among protestants I doubt there is much support.

I also think it fails a test of asking, "Is this what God wants, what God wills?" I imagine God would want Christians to be doing something else.

What do you think? Do any of these objections seem persuasive?
body_html:

the +boomers have in my view done little to address the issue so it's just being dumped on the future generations, which is frustrating

According to this article in the Milwaukee Journal in 1914, when tango proved to be too popular for his ban to have any effect, Pope Pius allegedly took a different tact; mocking the tango and trying to renew people’s interest in the “Furiana” (sic: correctly spelled Furlana), a 16th century dance that had gone out of fashion by 1750. Dancing Tango was still a sin in the 20th century.

So "moshing" is probably out by the same kind of logic for Catholics, it's an indiscriminately violent dance.

And then the argument would go, if the tango is banned and this is "tamer" than "Christian hardcore music", then such music would also be banned.

I imagine the orthodox would feel similarly, but I don't know

Even among protestants, some of the fundamentalists opposed the tango

body:
> who are the Christian authorities that have approved of "Christian hardcore"?

Why does a human organization that declares itself an authority have to approve something for it to not be wrong? And why does this only apply to certain things and not others, with no real reason for either?
body_html:
who are the Christian authorities that have approved of "Christian hardcore"?

Why does a human organization that declares itself an authority have to approve something for it to not be wrong? And why does this only apply to certain things and not others, with no real reason for either?

body:
> it's a reasonable question, I did a post on rock music being potentially of "the Devil"

What about listening to a certain kind of beat or rhythm is breaking the golden rule? I suppose if you blast it in front of people who don't want to hear it but that applies to anything.

parent.body:
it's a reasonable question, I did a post on rock music being potentially of "the Devil"

the origins of rock and jazz themselves were often associated with rebellion and cultures of sin (drugs, fornication, etc.)

so then people want to "baptize" or "Christianize" the movement, I could see that

But I think it would be like a Christian bikini - bikinis in themselves are immodest, it would be a contradiction to try to make them "Christian"

I guess I think if a Christian has "hardcore" passions of anger, maybe they could try to pour those in to prayer, work, or some other kind of music like religious or dramatic classical

body:
I think it might be rejected for the same reason of people talking about drugs like:

> what's the big deal with doing drugs, it's just an arrangement of molecules, who cares?

that arrangement of molecules creates drunkenness (in certain instances), which is a sin if produced for that reason

likewise that beat configuration is judged to be worldly and immodest in itself, as related to the rhythm of reproduction

body: Drugs actually harm you and that is scientifically proven. People listening to music you don't like does not unless the goal is to make everyone be like you. If it's not because you don't like it, what's "worldly and immodest" about an instrumental arrangement? You can't distinguish between good and bad with that outside of personal taste, which shows that it's not either. Is all music bad then? And if so, why?

If it's not because you don't like it, what's "worldly and immodest" about an instrumental arrangement? You can't distinguish between good and bad with that outside of personal taste, which shows that it's not either. Is all music bad then? And if so, why?

post.title: Christian hardcore

body:
If you really want to try to get to the bottom of this we could keep discussing it with a going back and forth

I was brought up to view it as "normal" and then some people said it was bad so then I did some research and concluded likewise that it seems wrong

issue one would be problematic lyrics - I doubt you disagree there

issue two seems to be the repetitive drum beat, it's either thought to be indecent in itself, puts people in a trance like drugs, etc.

another issue I wasn't really thinking of but when you said that drugs harm people but it was implied that rock music for example doesn't as much, I've heard music can have a certain effect on the brain, for example:

> A study reported by the Scripps Howard News Service found that exposure to rock music causes abnormal neuron structures in the region of the brain associated with learning and memory. https://www.arlenetaylor.org/music-and-the-brain/7410-potential-negative-impact

contrasted with

> Listening to classical music "down-regulated" genes that can be associated with neurodegenerative diseases, which goes to show that music helps keep the brain healthy. https://sites.psu.edu/classicalpassion/2016/06/30/classical-music-and-the-brain/

another issue is the surrounding culture it's a part of, that drug use and the music and fornication often go hand in hand

another issue is that certain songs can stir up passions which lead to sin

For myself I also concluded I don't think God wants me to listen to it - I didn't view it as something God positively willed or wanted

Various authorities have come out against it

I could try to find more reasons if desired - I will however admit that it's something that to me seems clear in theory, but not as much in practice since I like music

A study reported by the Scripps Howard News Service found that exposure to rock music causes abnormal neuron structures in the region of the brain associated with learning and memory. https://www.arlenetaylor.org/music-and-the-brain/7410-potential-negative-impact

Listening to classical music "down-regulated" genes that can be associated with neurodegenerative diseases, which goes to show that music helps keep the brain healthy. https://sites.psu.edu/classicalpassion/2016/06/30/classical-music-and-the-brain/

For myself I also concluded I don't think God wants me to listen to it - I didn't view it as something God positively willed or wanted

I could try to find more reasons if desired - I will however admit that it's something that to me seems clear in theory, but not as much in practice since I like music

parent.body: Drugs actually harm you and that is scientifically proven. People listening to music you don't like does not unless the goal is to make everyone be like you. If it's not because you don't like it, what's "worldly and immodest" about an instrumental arrangement? You can't distinguish between good and bad with that outside of personal taste, which shows that it's not either. Is all music bad then? And if so, why?

If it's not because you don't like it, what's "worldly and immodest" about an instrumental arrangement? You can't distinguish between good and bad with that outside of personal taste, which shows that it's not either. Is all music bad then? And if so, why?

post.body: Anyone remember how in the 90s there was a whole Christian presence in the general music scene? I bet @archibaldcoolstep would fucking tear it up w me if we put Zao on.

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
> issue one would be problematic lyrics - I doubt you disagree there

Those are lyrics. Words have meanings. The subject is songs without problematic lyrics.

> issue two seems to be the repetitive drum beat, it's either thought to be indecent in itself, puts people in a trance like drugs, etc.

This is where you start getting weird. It sounds, to me, like a complicated way of saying "I don't like it". Or someone else told you that and you blindly believe them. Music by definition has a beat. So is all music bad? It wasn't banned even in the Old Testament.

> another issue I wasn't really thinking of but when you said that drugs harm people but it was implied that rock music for example doesn't as much, I've heard music can have a certain effect on the brain, for example:

Some things can be more distracting than others. That's only a big deal if you're the all work and no play type.

> another issue is the surrounding culture it's a part of, that drug use and the music and fornication often go hand in hand

How would Christian music be associated with that?

> another issue is that certain songs can stir up passions which lead to sin

Anything with words can do that.

> Various authorities have come out against it

Various authorities also had Jesus crucified.
body_html:
issue one would be problematic lyrics - I doubt you disagree there

Those are lyrics. Words have meanings. The subject is songs without problematic lyrics.

issue two seems to be the repetitive drum beat, it's either thought to be indecent in itself, puts people in a trance like drugs, etc.

This is where you start getting weird. It sounds, to me, like a complicated way of saying "I don't like it". Or someone else told you that and you blindly believe them. Music by definition has a beat. So is all music bad? It wasn't banned even in the Old Testament.

another issue I wasn't really thinking of but when you said that drugs harm people but it was implied that rock music for example doesn't as much, I've heard music can have a certain effect on the brain, for example:

Some things can be more distracting than others. That's only a big deal if you're the all work and no play type.

another issue is the surrounding culture it's a part of, that drug use and the music and fornication often go hand in hand

How would Christian music be associated with that?

another issue is that certain songs can stir up passions which lead to sin

Anything with words can do that.

Various authorities have come out against it

Various authorities also had Jesus crucified.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

guild.name: Christianity

parent.body:
If you really want to try to get to the bottom of this we could keep discussing it with a going back and forth

I was brought up to view it as "normal" and then some people said it was bad so then I did some research and concluded likewise that it seems wrong

issue one would be problematic lyrics - I doubt you disagree there

issue two seems to be the repetitive drum beat, it's either thought to be indecent in itself, puts people in a trance like drugs, etc.

another issue I wasn't really thinking of but when you said that drugs harm people but it was implied that rock music for example doesn't as much, I've heard music can have a certain effect on the brain, for example:

> A study reported by the Scripps Howard News Service found that exposure to rock music causes abnormal neuron structures in the region of the brain associated with learning and memory. https://www.arlenetaylor.org/music-and-the-brain/7410-potential-negative-impact

contrasted with

> Listening to classical music "down-regulated" genes that can be associated with neurodegenerative diseases, which goes to show that music helps keep the brain healthy. https://sites.psu.edu/classicalpassion/2016/06/30/classical-music-and-the-brain/

another issue is the surrounding culture it's a part of, that drug use and the music and fornication often go hand in hand

another issue is that certain songs can stir up passions which lead to sin

For myself I also concluded I don't think God wants me to listen to it - I didn't view it as something God positively willed or wanted

Various authorities have come out against it

I could try to find more reasons if desired - I will however admit that it's something that to me seems clear in theory, but not as much in practice since I like music

issue two seems to be the repetitive drum beat, it's either thought to be indecent in itself, puts people in a trance like drugs, etc.

another issue I wasn't really thinking of but when you said that drugs harm people but it was implied that rock music for example doesn't as much, I've heard music can have a certain effect on the brain, for example:

A study reported by the Scripps Howard News Service found that exposure to rock music causes abnormal neuron structures in the region of the brain associated with learning and memory. https://www.arlenetaylor.org/music-and-the-brain/7410-potential-negative-impact

contrasted with

Listening to classical music "down-regulated" genes that can be associated with neurodegenerative diseases, which goes to show that music helps keep the brain healthy. https://sites.psu.edu/classicalpassion/2016/06/30/classical-music-and-the-brain/

another issue is the surrounding culture it's a part of, that drug use and the music and fornication often go hand in hand

another issue is that certain songs can stir up passions which lead to sin

For myself I also concluded I don't think God wants me to listen to it - I didn't view it as something God positively willed or wanted

Various authorities have come out against it

I could try to find more reasons if desired - I will however admit that it's something that to me seems clear in theory, but not as much in practice since I like music
